thread.title: Winter storm watches declared for much of East Idaho in anticipation of weekend snowstorm | APG State News | idahopress.com
thread.title_full: Winter storm watches declared for much of East Idaho in anticipation of weekend snowstorm | APG State News | idahopress.com

author: Journal Staff
title: Winter storm watches declared for much of East Idaho in anticipation of weekend snowstorm | APG State News | idahopress.com
text:
Winter storm watches have been declared for several higher elevation areas in East Idaho in anticipation of a snowstorm that is expected to hit the region Friday through Sunday.
The National Weather Service's forecast for East Idaho is calling for a chance of snow all three days. Pocatello, Chubbuck and several other local cities received light snow Friday morning and more is on the way.
The snowiest span is forecast to be Saturday morning through Sunday afternoon, with many of East Idaho's higher elevation areas bracing for several inches of snow.
The weather service said 5 to 12 inches of snow could fall Saturday morning through Sunday afternoon in the Island Park, Driggs, Victor, Tetonia, Dubois, Mud Lake, Spencer, Idaho National Laboratory, Craters of the Moon, Palisades, Swan Valley, Bone, Wayan, Henry, Ashton, Arco and Emigration Summit areas.
Travel in these areas "could be very difficult to impossible" because of the snowstorm, the weather service stated.

The region's other highland areas including Soda Springs, Montpelier, Inkom, Arbon, Rockland and Lava Hot Springs as well as most lowland areas including Pocatello, Chubbuck, Blackfoot, Idaho Falls, Rexburg, Preston, American Falls, Aberdeen and Malad could receive up to three inches of snow this weekend.
It's likely that the snow will switch to rain at times this weekend, especially in lower elevation areas.
Elsewhere in Idaho, winter storm watches are in effect in the central mountains including the Stanley, Hailey, Ketchum, Sun Valley and Mackay areas and in parts of southwest Idaho.
Winter weather warnings have also been declared in parts of Oregon, Washington state and Wyoming because of the storm.
Stay with idahostatejournal.com for updates on this story.
